subject: Running periodic tasks in separate process.
commit_message:
Running periodic tasks in separate process.

Combine periodic tasks and main jobs into one process make service work slow.
Especially when there are lots of instances, periodic tasks will eat lots of
time. What make main server hard to do response to RPC request as quickly as it
can. Since main jobs and periodic tasks share nothing, So extract periodic
tasks into a separate process can work perfectly.

This patch create a new config entry named "use_separate_periodic" to indicate
whether running periodic tasks in separete process. When launcher server,
set one of the processes's enable_periodic to False, and set another to True.
So one process will not run periodic tasks absolutely, another will only run
periodic task.

Fix bug #1078811

subject: Fix nova-manage sub-command argument processing
commit_message:
Fix nova-manage sub-command argument processing

The legacy implementation added double dash '--' to every argument of
sub-commands. To remain compatible of this (i.e. legacy automation scripts
based on nova-manage), after converting to OSLO's cfg, which is based on
python argparse module, double dash remains.
However, current implementation doesn't distinguish required/optional
arguments of sub-command, but instead using a late-check
(cliutils.validate_args()) to verify if enough parameters have been supplied
before executing the commands.  While this does prevent invalid input of
arguments but the out-put after detecting a missing argument problem isn't
helpful at all.  A easier and elegant way is to make arguement declaration
correct, then argparse will verify input for us and prompt meaningful error
message.  What's more, treating every argument as optional (that's how
argparse sees the arguments) makes help message very very confusing. Last
but not least, current implementation adds a 'action_args' argument to every
sub-command which takes multiple optional arguements (nargs='*'), this
doesn't make sense since each sub-command defines what arguments they need,
there's no need to add an additional general action_args.

This patch does following to fix issues mentioned above:
 * remove unnecessary 'metavar' for arguements;
 * add 'required=True' to those required arguments while keeping double dash;
 * remove redundant 'dest' for arguments;
 * add missing argument declaration for HostCommands and LogCommands;
 * add missing help message for CellCommands;
 * change the way nova-mange to retrieve arguments of sub-commands;
 * remove general 'action_args';
 * remove cliutils.validate_args() since it's not needed anymore;

subject: Fix circular dependencies in dashboard settings
commit_message:
Fix circular dependencies in dashboard settings

Importing horizon.utils from dashboard local_settings.py to generate
SECRET_KEY results in a sequence of imports, and horizon.conf.default
module gets imported at some point. During initialization of default
HORIZON_CONFIG this module uses settings.LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL and
ugettext() call. Both of them need django settings to be ready to use,
therefore settings initialization starts again before it could finish.

Since Python processes module only when it is imported the first time,
this process stops, but the 'inner' settings object contains only
parameters that were set above the point of import of local_settings.
Therefore Django complains about missing SECRET_KEY when it processes
'inner' settings.

The fix moves the import of horizon.conf.default to
LazySetting._setup(). If keys of HORIZON_CONFIG obtained from
horizon.conf are not used within openstask_dashboard settings.py
or local_settings.py, the circular import won't happen.

Fixes bug #1154564

subject: Fixes instance task_state being left as migrating
commit_message:
Fixes instance task_state being left as migrating

In a cross-hypervisor environment, such as KVM + Hyper-v. After negative test
which live migrate a KVM instance to Hyper-v host, there will be an exception
InvalidHypervisorType. As a result, the instance task_state is being
left as migrating. That leaves the instance in a broken state and most of the
requests on the instance will fail.

Actually, there are some other exceptions will cause this issue as well, such
as UnableToMigrateToSelf, DestinationHypervisorTooOld. All of them are thrown
from the driver of scheduler during live migration. But obviously, if the live
migration fails at the schedule stage, the task_state of the target instance
should be updated to None.

Fixes Bug: 1153283

subject: Fixes Hyper-V live migration with attached volumes
commit_message:
Fixes Hyper-V live migration with attached volumes

Fixes bug: 1153429

The previous Hyper-V driver live migration implementation expects to find iSCSI
devices mounted on the same path on source and destination, which is not an
option in this context.

In order to be able to live migrate instances with attached volumes, this fix
provides the following behavior, based on the creation of a staged VM on the
target, so called "planned" in the Hyper-V documentation and in this patch.

pre_live_migration

The target host logs into the storage targets.

live_migration

The source host:

1) checks and removes a previously created planned VM for the current
   instance if present on the target
2) creates a planned VM on the target by using the Hyper-V WMI API
3) maps the volume devices on the planned VM based on the target host
   devices
4) live migrates the source VM on the planned VM
5) logs off the storage targets on the source

This solution provides live migration of volumes without needing to pause
the VM and detach / attach the volumes, preserving also the atomicity of the
live operation.

In the case in which no volumes are attached to the VM, live migration is
performed without creating explicitly a planned VM, starting from step 4
on the source in the above list.

Unit tests have been added for this scenario.

Change-Id: Ib634b77894f492896d86dce65a7269ece8f3d55b

Fixes bug #1098700.

Previously, deleting then re-creating an image member failed with
500 ServerError due to the registry service failing to commit
the update to the image_members table.

The problem arose because the declared uniqueness constraint on that
table only spanned the image_id and member columns, but did not take

and deleted columns set as appropriate. Hence the unique constraint
was violated by the addition of the new row.

account of the deleted_at column also (NULL for live memberships).

subject: Add a region tier to Swift's ring.
commit_message:
Add a region tier to Swift's ring.

The region is one level above the zone; it is intended to represent a
chunk of machines that is distant from others with respect to
bandwidth and latency.

Old rings will default to having all their devices in region 1. Since
everything is in the same region by default, the ring builder will
simply distribute across zones as it did before, so your partition
assignment won't move because of this change. If you start adding
devices in other regions, of course, the assignment will change to
take that into account.

swift-ring-builder still accepts the same syntax as before, but will
default added devices to region 1 if no region is specified.

Examples:

$ swift-ring-builder foo.builder add r2z1-1.2.3.4:555/sda

$ swift-ring-builder foo.builder add r1z3-1.2.3.4:555/sda

$ swift-ring-builder foo.builder add z3-1.2.3.4:555/sda

Also, some updates to ring-overview doc.

nova-manage: add 'required=True'

Add 'required=True' to those required arguments while keeping double dash.

The legacy implementation added double dash '--' to every argument of
sub-commands. To remain compatible of this (i.e. legacy automation scripts
based on nova-manage), after converting to OSLO's cfg, which is based on
python argparse module, double dash remains.
However, current implementation doesn't distinguish required/optional
arguments of sub-command, but instead using a late-check
(cliutils.validate_args()) to verify if enough parameters have been supplied
before executing the commands.  While this does prevent invalid input of
arguments but the out-put after detecting a missing argument problem isn't
helpful at all.  A easier and elegant way is to make arguement declaration
correct, then argparse will verify input for us and prompt meaningful error
message.  What's more, treating every argument as optional (that's how
argparse sees the arguments) makes help message very very confusing. Last
but not least, current implementation adds a 'action_args' argument to every
sub-command which takes multiple optional arguements (nargs='*'), this
doesn't make sense since each sub-command defines what arguments they need,
there's no need to add an additional general action_args.

subject: xenapi: Fix reboot with hung volumes
commit_message:
xenapi: Fix reboot with hung volumes

If a volume becomes inoperable (e.g. the ISCSI connection is severed)
and the user goes to reboot, the instance may enter a permanently halted
state.

The root cause is that a VBD that points to 'bad' volume prevents VM
operations ('reboot', 'start') from completing under XenServer.

The work around is to detect which volumes are bad, detach in the
virt-layer, retry the operation (or in the case of reboot, just 'start'
the halted instance), and then notify the compute manager via a
callback so it can detach the volume in Cinder.

Fixes bug 1148614

setup in Grizzly, set fixed_range='' in your nova.conf. The intention
